South America, East, South and West Africa,

be marked Via Eastern.

Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

div.head: Newly Discovered MSS of The Bible.
div.p: "Four newly discovered MSS. of the Bible were reported at the meeting of the Archæological Institute of America." says the New York "Nation," "Prof. H. A. Sanders, of the University of Michigan, reported on four manuscripts of the Bible, now in the possession of Charles L Freer, of Detroit. The manuscripta were bought by Mr Freer early in 1907 in Egypt. They were probably buried or lost at the time of the Moslem conquest in 639 A.D. At any rate the manuscripts all date that period, nor, in the opinion of Professor Sanders, do they contain any inarks of a second hand even, which can be placed later than this date.

"Two of the manuscripts are in a large ancial hand, two in small, and there are other variations sufficient to convince Prof. Sander that the individual manuscripts were written at different dates, ranging from the third to the sixth century. He refers to the manuscripts by the Roman numerals I, II, III, and IV. Manuscript I now contains Deuteronomy and Joshua; Genesis to Numbers inclusive, which it once contained, are missing. It is next to the oldest of the four manuscripts, and presents an exceptionally accurate text of this portion of the Septuagint. Manuscript II, contains the Psalms. Although it is the oldest manuscript of the four, and is badly decayed, large portions of every Psalm will prove recoverable. A comparison of a portion of the text shows that it is one of the best manuscripts of the Psalms in existence; in the large portions where the Vaticanus fails, it is perhaps the very best.

"Manuscript III. contains the four Gospels entirely. It was probably written in the fifth or sixth century, and contains many interesting variant readings. It is most important, however, because it contains the following extra paragraph :

"And they answered, saying that this age of unrighteousness and unbelief is under the power of Satan, who does not permit the things which are made impure by the (ovil) spirits to comprehend the truth of God (and) his power. For this reason, "Reveal thy righteousness now," they said to Christ, and Christ said to them: "The limit of the years of the power of Satan has been fulfilled, but other terrible things are at hand, and I was delivered unto death on behalf of those who sinned in order that they may return to the truth and sin no more, to the end that they may inherit the spiritual, indestructible glory of righteousness (which) is in heaven."

"This new paragraph was known to St. Jerome, and the first few lines of it are oited in Latin translation. It has long been held that Mark xvi. 8-20 was a state addition to the Gospel, thought to have been borrowed from some other unknown Gospel near the end of the second century. This new manuscript probably presents the original form of that part of the lost Gospel, which, mutilated, was added to Mark. The reason for the omission is quite apparent, as the new verse contains the statement that the destruction of sin in the world is near at hand. This idea is found in the epistles of Peter and Paul, but the four Gospels do not have it, and it is avoided by the later Church writers.

"Manuscript IV. is only a badly decayed fragment. It once contained Acts and the Epistles, but not Revelations. It is an older and better manascript than the four Gospels, and its readings will be of value."

div.head: Watfo Administration
div.p: The Superior Council of Wakfs will meet tomorrow in Cairo under the presidency of Has. san Pasha Rushdi.

div.head: The Republican Party
div.p: It is announced that the party of the Republic is about to issue a monthly review in support of their policy.

div.head: Cholera Precautions
div.p: A credit of LE 7,000 has been granted to cover the expenses to be incurred for the precautionary measures against cholera.

div.head: Quarantine
div.p: The following telegram has been received from Athens - "Medical inspection in lieu of quarantine for arrivals from the Mediterranean ports of Egypt."

div.head: Cobbo Boy's Transferment
div.p: Cobbe Bey, who recently transferred from the Alexandria Police Force to the Inspectorate of the Interior, has also been given an increase of salary to LE 550 per annum.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre
div.p: The performances given by Door Leblane at the Alhambra theatre are proving an enormous success; indeed this famous artist and his troupe are thoroughly supporting the fame they have attained.

div.head: New Crimes Bureau
div.p: A new office for control of crime in Egypt has been created at the Ministry of the Interior. Mr. Hornblower has been appointed director and Hashim Bey, late of Alexandria Public Security, chef du bureau.

div.head: The Brindiel Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe vin Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O. Alexandria, at 8.10 p. m. on Sunday 26th for ordinary correspondents, at noon for money orders and insured articles and at 6 p. m. on Saturday 25th for parolees.

div.head: A Noted Violinist
div.p: Mr. Marsick, the noted violinist, gave a most enjoyable concert last night with the ad of Dr. Frey, Mr. P. Erlich, Madame Jesumann, and Mr. Jacot des Combes. We are glad to learn that Mr. Marsick will give a matinée concert on the 31st inst, when doubtless all lovers of music will flock to hear him.

div.head: Bubonic Plague
div.p: Eight fresh cases of plague were recorded for the week ending January 21st, four at Minieh, three at Deirout, and one at Tantah. During the last 24 hours four cases have been discharged from hospital, two at Minieh and two At Deirout, one death being reported from the latter town. Twenty cases are now under treatment and the total for the month of January up to the 21st inst. was forty eight.

div.head: Ball at Khartoum
div.p: On the 17th inst. the Royal Engineers, E.A, gave a ball at the Grand Hotel, Khartoum. The hotel was beautifully decorated on that Occasion, mostly by the officers themselves who took great deal of trouble to make the ball successful. The gardens were very artistically illuminated. 180 set down for supper, which WAS served in the open air. The croquet lawn of the Hotel was converted into a huge drawing room. Dancing went on till 3 a.m.

div.head: Lamplough's Ploturee
div.p: Mr. Lamplough's exhibition of water-colour drawings at the Hotel d'Angleterre continue to attract a large number of people, and to his already perfect collection he has now added the sketches which he has made since his arrival in Cairo a short while ago. A feature of his work of this season will be painting of a series of well-known scenes of Cairo which the hand of time and the exigencies of modern life have doomed to destruction. All of us know and appreciate Mr. Lamplough's genius in reproducing the scenes peculiar to this country, and this latest collection of disappearing Cairo should prove of great value.

div.head: Egypt's Trade
div.p: November Customs Returns

During last month the value of goods imported into Egypt was L. E. 2,383,904, being LE. 210,976 less than December 1906, while for the year with an import value of L. E. 25,404,576 an increase of L. E. 2,089,283. is shown. Last month the exports totalled LE 3,868 007 against LE. 4 290,118 during December 1906, and since the 1st of January L. E. 28,013, 185 against L E 24,877,280. Classifying the various imports and exports we get the following figures for the year:-- Animals and animal foods -- Imports L E. 1,284,811; Exports L.E. 131,010. Skins and works in skins. Imports L B. 464,637; Exports I. B 148,256. Other animal products--Imports L.B. 92,476 Exports L.E. 110,274. Cereals, vegetables, and corns. - Imports LE. 2,963,931; Exports L.E. 3,189,506. Colonial roots and drugs. - Imports L E. 759,495 ; Exports L E. 113,823. Spirits, liquors, and oils - Imports L. E. 1,151,518; Exports L E. 13,957. Chiffons, papers, and books-Imports L E. 405,357 ; Exports LE. 19,725. Wood and coal. -- Imports 3,407,021 ; Ex | ports of wood L.E. 17,909. Stone, earth, Wessels, glasses, and crystals. Imports L. E. 774,420 ; Exports L.E. 5,100. Tinctures and colours. -- Imports LE 291,969 ; Exports L.E. 23,859 Chemical and medicinal products and perfumes. - Imports L.E. 762,111 ; Exports LE 28,753. Textile industries. -- Imports LB-7,006,851 Exports (cotton included) LE. 23,782,570. Metals and work in metal. - Imports LE. 3,960,584 ; Exports LB 3,906. Various articles, - Imports LE 2,083,075 Exports L.E. 81,528. Taking the total imports and exports for the principal countries for the year, we having the following figures : England - Imported L E. 8,705,917, Exported L E 15,237,411. Prance-Imported LE. 3,227,669 ; Export ed LE. 2,049,000, Turkey ---Imported LE. 2,973,108, Exported LE. 337,410. Austro-Hungary --Imported LE. 2,059,423; Exported LE 1,315,397.. Germany-Imported LE. 1,392,381 x Ex. ported LE. 2,252,954. Italy -Imported LE. 1,361,457 ; Exported LE. 791,044. Russia --Imported LE. 676,868 ; Exported LE. 1,599,580. - Greece-Imported L.E. 342,322 : Exported LE. 24,729.
Exchange of Specie

The total of specie imported last month was LE 498,818 as compared with LE. 1,515,659 in December 1906. During the year the import of specie was LE 7,768,190 as compared with LE 9,077,402 last year. Of the L.E. 7,768,190 imported during the year of LE. 4,806,074 came from England and LE. 1.446,625 from Turkey. The specie exported during last month was LE. 38,320 as compared with L. E. 40,714 in December 1906, and for the year the figures are L E 4,736,*89 and L.E. 2,067,706 respectively for 1907 and 1906. Of the exported specie during the year LE 2,118,215 went to England LE. 1,726,828 to India, LE. 488,885 to Turkey, and L E.361,680 to France.
Cigarette Trade

The total export of cigarettes during December was 44,980 kilos, as compared with 46,240 in December 1906 and from the 1st of January to 31st December the figures recorded for 1907 and 1906 respectively are 491,894 kilos, and 590,047. Of the 491,894 kilos, exported during the past year 153,786 went to Germany; 87,780 to England ; 69,015 to British possessions in the Far East; 44,350 to Austro-Hungary; 25,874 to China and the Far East; 23,221 to France; 14.240 to America ; and 12,096 to Belgium.

div.head: Merchant Seamen's Home
div.p: New Year's Treat

The annual New Year's Treat provided by the Ramleb ladies for seamen was given at the T Home on Wednesday last. The occasion is a very popular one with the men, and is looked forward to by those who have the good fortune to be, at the time, arriving at the port. As on so many prior anniversaries, the entertainment was organized by Mr Mose who had proved into the service many willing helpers. The lørge hall was decorated with tags lent from ships in the harbour, and with greenery supplied by Mrs Moss and Mrs. Cratton, the Arrangement being most effectively carried out by Captain Dingle (the manager of the Hne) and his assistants. The front of the pla prm presented a most pleasing effect, borrod with clumps of arum lilies. During the per each man was presented with #paokot of tobacco and a New Year's card (a personal gift from Mrs. Mose) and a buttonhole. Some 180 men did justice to a repast consisting of turkey, bam, joints, fruit, cake and tes, at the concert which followed an enthusiastic audience numbering with late comers, at least 250, testified their appreciation by hearty applause. Some members of the Blind School were present and appeared to enjoy the music. The musical part of the entertainment was again arranged by Mr. Hilary Moss the programme being as follows, many res being demanded.
Miss H. Wilson, Piano solo.
Mr. D. Allen, song, "Pinkerton's role Pills."
Miss Hewat and Miss K. Murphy, violin duet.
W.J.B. Clarke, song, "Cabal River."
Mrs. EG C. Moss, song, "Sunbeams."
Mr. H.E.C. Moss, song, "Lucky Jim."
Miss B. Murphy, song, "The Kerry Dance."
Mrs.J. Hicks Paull, Recitation. "The Alarm."
Mr. Aydon, song.
Captain Gardner, song, 'Of he went at seven in the morning."
Mr. D. Allen, song, "The Coster's Mansion."
Mr. J.B. Clarke, song, "I love a Lassi
Mr. T. Ryanı'', song, "I was watching 'en."
Mr. H.E.C. Moss, song, "Teasing."
The piano accompanists were Miss H. Wilson (who worked exceedingly bard), Mrs. Hicks Paall and the Rev. EH. Blyth.

At the conclusion Mr. Blyth, who had acted As chairman, called for three cheers for the Rainleh ladies and for all who had taken part in the cocoert. The response was tremulous, even for a Seamen's Home gathering three cheers more were given for the chairman and the evening closed by all joining in singing the National Anthem.

div.head: The Abdin Incident
div.p: The Sheikh Razi incident continues to arouse the keenest excitement and interest in native circles and contradictory rumours are as usual published and repeated as facts in every direction. If all the versions current in the native Press are accurate then we are faced by the fact that Sheikh Razi was and is, at one and the same time, a bigoted reactionary and a pestilent revolutionary, an impious wretch and a virtuous cleric, that he was expelled from the Khedivial reception on the ground of a personal quarrel with a member of the Maieh Sanieb, and that he left Abdin on his own motion on hearing that H. H. The Khedive declined to receive him, etc. etc. In any case, it is quite certain that a group of Ulema who had made certain complaints concerning the administration of the Al Azhar University, was admitted to the presence of his Highness at the Courban Beiram reception and by him severely reprimanded. Their excuse was the usual one – "it was the other boy that did it, Sir, not me," and Sheikh Razi was held responsible. "Al Akhbar" adds that the Sheikh who has been loud in his complaints was recently informed that if he continued to discuss his grievances in public he would be degraded from his office. Meanwhile "Al Zaher" deplores a national calamity and brings out funereal columns with the deepest and blackest borders and the non-Moslem public demands more anxiously – who is Sheikh Razi "What has he done." Can "Al Moayad" or "Al Garida" give us a good account of the incident and its causes ?"

div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion.

div.head: Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Company
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir --Referring to the letter signed "Observer" in your issue of yesterday I beg to state that the statutes of the above named company provision is made for operating "dans des pays limitrophes à l'Egypte'' and the opening of business in Cyprus was voted in due form at a general meeting of shareholders held a few months after the company's formation. As on this point "Observer" seems to have misunderstood the letter signed by myself and colleagues which appeared in your number of the 22nd instant, others of your readers may have likewise done so. You will therefore find room for this rectification in your columna. There may possibly be cases in which the suggestions of "Observer" might prove exceedingly pertinent and useful, but they are not of application to the Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co. The success of the company in Cyprus will depend on the degree to which intelligence and a rigid economy are exercised in the administration there, but the directors were unquestionably entirely within their rights in opening business in the island.
Faithfully yours,

div.head: Egyptian Bonded Warehouses
div.p: The Egyptian Bonded Warehouses Company Limited have already begun working the freight service of the Express Nile Steamers Limited. There are fourteen steam barges and some tenders belonging to the Express Nile Company.

The Bonded Warehouses have also come to an arrangement with the Hamburg AngloAmerican Line in regard to Nile freight traffic whereby there will be no cutting of rates in future between the two companies.

The Bonded Warehouses has purchased a large piece of land on the banks of the Nile at Boulac with a frontage of 120 metres. A quay and general warehouses are to be built immediately for landing and receiving goods by river.

div.head: The Cholera
div.p: False Report in "Times"
We are astonished to read the following report in the weekly edition of our London contemporary the "Times" :
"A bulletin issued at Cairo says that 27 cases of cholera have occurred. At Mecca there have been 241 deaths, but none at Jeddah."
We can safely assert that no such bulletin was issued, as there has as yet been no case of cholera either in this country or in Sudan.

We trust that our contemporary will immediately rectify their error, which may prove deplorably detrimental to Egypt. The report will be eagerly seized upon and enlarged by those who are responsible for booming rival winter resorts, and, emanating from the paper which has the highest standing in the world of journalism, will be relieved by all who read it.
We trust that in the interests of the Egyptian public the "Times" will give prominence to an emphatic contradiction of so damaging and so false a report.
The upmost possible precautions are being taken by the authorities to exclude the disease, and, though its advent is possible, it is at the same time probable that we shall escape it altogether.
We greatly deplore the fact that the first newspaper of the world should have given publically to this incorrect news, the effect of which no one can at present judge.

div.p: A goodly assortment of people favoured the Semiramis on Wednesday evening both for dinner and the dance afterwards; & very great improvement being noticed in the condition of the ball room from week to week. Several parties came over from Ghezireh, and there were quite a number of Cairo residents and visitors from the other hotels in addition to those who are already staying at the Semiramis which like the rest is filling up fast.

Tuan Campang, Mr. and Miss FitzClarence, Dr. Tribe, Mr.R. G. Orred, Baron de Villenfangue, Mr. and Mme. Cattaui, Mr. and Mrs Alexander, Menards. Adda, Mme Aghion, Messrs. div.head: Zizinia Theatre
div.p: "Lohengrin"

With the production of Wagner's "Lohengrin" the Societa Artistica of Alexandria have placed before their ever appreciative audience perhaps the most successful attempt this season. The opera itself is too well known to require mach comment at this period. It might be of interest however to remark that Lohengrin, Knight of the Holy Grail, is introduced as a symbol of Christianity defeating the Frieslandish heathenism in the wiles and machinations of the sorceress Ortrud.

After the splendid performance of Signorina Salomca Crucsenski in "Madame Butterfly" it was a foregone conclusion that her "Elsa" would be, at least, in no degree inferior to any previous interpretation of the character on the Zizina stage. Last night's production clearly proved this. Her performance was throughout, artistic in the extreme A delightful rendering of one of Wagner's tenderest compositions, a rendering overflowing with inexpressible sweetness and played with perfect grace.

As "Lohengrin" Signor Italo Cristalli met with very hearty appreciation. He contributed considerably to the entire success of the opera and with Signorina Crusceniski on several occasions moved the large audience to a pitch of unwonted enthusiasm.

Signor Oreste Benedetti's "Federico" was a very meritorious performance and in conjunction with Signorina Margherita Julia, who gave an excellent portrayal of the rather thankless, and at the same time extremely difficult, rôle of Ortroda, scored a distinct success.

Signor Lodovico Contini appeared hardly sufficiently robust for the trying music of King Enrico, but his rendering was on the whole a good one. A special word of praise is also due to the "Herald," Signor F. Rosconi.

Signor Giovanni Zaocani is to be congratulated on the excellence of his orchestra, and the chorus master is certainly to be complimented upon the high degree of perfection attained in his particular sphere.

div.head: Abbas Theatre, Cairo
div.p: "La Boheme."

Surely no more touching and exquisite Mimi than Signora Coniglio could be seen. Not a detail of her acting, not a least inflection of her voice but was perfect, telling, memorable, not merely for Cairo but for any stage. So quiet, so charming, knowing her world of mirth and sorrow, hunger and gaiety 80 well, no intent a listener, waiting on her lover's every word, so pathetic in her resignation and sympathy at the last, surely she moved all as she indeed moved some of us. The beauty of the 'addio' song, all its sad knowledge, and hope -"addio sospetti!"-farewell doubt and trouble, farewell sorrow, farewell all, seve pity and love.-she so well knew all love had brought and yet would bring, of happiness or unhappiness, - and the wonder of the death scene, were revealed as they seldom can be.

The rest of the performance was never, one must confess it. The conductor was by no means at his best in the second act, and he missed one or two entries of the singers badly. He can do far better than that, and we must hope it will be the last occurrence of its kind. Signor Ventara was not at his best until the very end : there he excelled, and his acting was fully worthy of the situation. His make-up was most trying, and he should really pay more attention there too. The general impression as to the others, was that they could do far better; they were not at their ease, and consequently the spirit and continuity of the performance was not maintained. The 'coat' song was embarrassed and uncertain and hardly deserved the encore it obtained But then one could not but contrast it with Signor Lucenti's masterly and faultless rendering last year.

Still these were all minor defects in a memorable performance. Manon Lescaut and LA Tosca are not at present being rehearsed. La Tosca should be especially noteworthy. I hope to see the three chief parts taken by Signor Coniglio, Sigtor Ventura, and Signor Challis That combination would ensure the needs of most operas and above all of La Tosca.

div.head: The German Hospital
div.p: Series of Concerts

The first concert for the benefit of the Deaconesses' Hospital, has been fixed for the 5th of February at the New Khedivial Hotel, to commence at 9.15 p.m. Among the musicians of note who will take part are Madame Stross, who, trained as a pianist at the Vienna conservatoire, is famed for her sympathetic execution ; Madame Jesumann,a mezzo-soprano with a most pleasing voice ; Dr. Stross, Dr. Frey, Mr. Jacot des Combes, and Mr. P. Ehrlich, the latter two of whom we have heard in conjunction with the famous violinist Mr. Marsick, who bas also consented to perform on this occasion. We must also mention Mix Verita, Mrs. E G.C. Moss, Mrs. Trelawney, Miss Hewat, Mr. Capozzi, and Mr. Gubsich, all of whom have promised to contribute to the programme. We trust that this concert will receive the full support which so admirable an object deserves.

div.head: Personal and Social

Mr. Hall Caine, who is staying with his wife at the Semiramis Hotel at Cairo, intends going for a trip up the Nile in company with Mr. Sidney Low, the well-known London journalist, who is making a prolonged stay in Egypt.

The Right Hon. Sir Ernest Cassel entertained a select party for dinner at the restaurant of the Savoy Hotel last evening. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. Birubaum, Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Schiff, Prince and Princess Teano, Mrs. Ashley, Capt. Stirling. Mr. Webb, and Birob Pasha. At other tables were : Mr. and Mrs. Louis Tiffani and party, Mr. and Mme. Leo Foul, Baron and Baroness Sehey and party, Mr. Heaton Armstrong M.P., Marquis Fioravanti and others.
Mr. and Mrs. Converse, the well-known American from New York, are staying at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo. Other arrivals include Baron and Baroness von Schey, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Foul, etc.

div.head: Lord Milner
div.p: London, Friday. Lord Milner has left for Egypt.

div.head: Weather at Home
div.p: London, Friday. London is enveloped in a dense fog.
The Clayton Company's steam launch No. 2 has arrived at Suez, ready for the disinfection of steamers.

The Russian Pilgrim Steamer "Gregory Morch'' which was ashore off Jeddah, and subsequently refloated by the Danish salvage steamer "Denmark", has now entered the K. M. S.S. and Graving Dock Co. dry dock at Suez for repairs.

Owing to the heavy rains of late the railway line between Fayed and Nefiche stations has been seriously interrupted, and the repairs will not be completed before Friday. In the meantime, passenger trains leaving Suez for Ismailis can only go up to the undamaged place, and on the other side the Ismailia train awaits to which passengers have to walk. The goods trains have been temporarily stopped both at Ismailis and Snez.

div.head: Aerated Water for Health
div.p: The importance of pure water, for drinking purposes cannot be overestimated and overy precaution should be taken, such as redistillation, to insure protection to health.
Many physicians advise drinking the ex. clusive use of carbonated or "fizz" waters, because the process of oxygenating water under pressure destroys all animate genus.
The robust health of the English and the consumption of more than 4,000,000 gallons of Aerated water in 1907 indicate the value of this method of preventing epidemics.

"The London Lancet, a high medical authority, in commenting upon this extensive use of effervescing beverages, stated that the effervescent properties of a liquid promote digestion in two ways-first, by the carbonic acid gas acting as a stimulant to the muscular movements of the stomach, and, second, by assisting in the disintegration of its contents. What interests most people, however, is not the scientific reasons for the extensive use of sparkling wine, like champagne, or of pare, effervescent water, like Tansan, but rather their availability and cost. "But we are learning once more in regard to water the lesson that the world has learned as to almost everything else we take into our systems; the count of purity is less than the cost of doctors' bills or than the supreme cost of death. The popular appreciation of this fact is in part reflected in the enactment of the pure food law. It is shown also in the growing use of effervescent water of assured purity and softness. A distinguished French physician says that man is as old as his arteries. Hard water hardens the arteries, soft water keeps them elastic and responsive to the pulse. Hence it is that the Japanese attribute much of their vitality, prowess, and progress to the generous use of their native sparkling water.”

div.head: DUKE OF CONNAUGHT.
div.p: VISIT TO EGYPT.
MALTA, January 24.

The Duke of Connaught will arrive at Alex Andria on the 12th February, Cairo on the 18th, and Khartoum on the 16th. His Highness will attend the maneuvers in the Fayoum from the 1st to sth March, and will leave Cairo for Malta on the 12th. (Reuter)

div.p: PEKING, January 23.
Sir Robert Hart has applied for two years leave of absence and has proposed to Mr. Bredon to replace him temporarily. (Reuter)

div.head: THE "AMSTERDAM" BEACHED.
div.p: The Hague, January 23.
The "Amsterdam" has been beached. A boat with 12 passengers and crew is missing. The fog is still very dense. (Reuter)
The Hague, January 23.
There are no tidings of the missing boat. It is now announced that the boat contained 28 persons, of whom 21 were passengers. The dense fog continues and is an impending search. (Reuter)

div.head: WINSTON CHURCHILL AT MANCHESTER.
div.p: London, January 23.

Mr. Winston Churchill, speaking of Manchester, said that he found in Uganda enormous regions where excellent cotton was growable. He believed that our equatorial possessions in time would constitute a valuable adjunct to the cotton supply.

Referring to the lock-out, he said he did not believe that Lancashire would imperil the livelihood of millions on an issue which narrowed down to a point that was understandable to nobody outside of that district. (Reuter)

div.head: FOOD AND DRINK. REVELATION OF FRAUDS.
div.p: "The strength of a nation depends upon the health of the people," said Dr. Bedloe of Washington D.C. to an "Egyptian Gazette" representative at the Khedivial last evening in speaking of the Pure Food Law now in force in America.

"The American people, "continued Dr. Bedloe, "have now a Pare Food Law, thanks to President Roosevelt and the American Congress, that protects the public from the rapacity of compounders of cheap and injurious food products that were formerly sold as genuine, thus obtaining money under false pretences and committing a crime against humanity.
"The Pure Food Law of the United States is the result of a demand on the part of the American people who now have protection similar to that in Great Britain.

The bill was long delayed in Congress by the opposition of a powerful lobby made up of a combination of compounders of spirituous liquors, such as experts at Shoomakers in Washington pronounce a brand of "that's all bad whiskey"; food adulteration; quack-medicine men and wicked beer-brewers; but 'vox populi prevailed.
"The law has been in forgoe a little more than a year and has already made a profound change in American industries and an improvement in public health.

"The enforcement of the Pure Food Law depends chiefly on the Bureau of Manufactures which is one of the bureaus of the department of commerce and labor under the direction of Secretary Oscar Strauss the renowned philanthropist of New York and former American Ambassador to Turkey.

"Major John M. Carson is the chief and executive head of the Bareau, an intelligent, aggressive and capable official who, for many years, was the Washington correspondent of The N.Y. Times and Philadelphia "Ledger." Chief Carson has done good work in organizing and directing a staff of special agents attached to his bureau for the purpose of investigating, exposing and checking frauds in the manufacture of food products. He has driven ont of the market such practices as using copper salts to color green-peas, string beans, and spinach aniline dyes to color beets, tomatoes, tomato ketchup, chili-sauce, cherries, ete: Salycilic acid and formalde-hyde to preserve milk-compounds, fish, sausage and many albuminoids ; the mixing of colza with olive oil; the substitution of bogus and sophisticated for genuine wines : the mixing of cocoa and chocolate with brown-starch and clay; the adulteration of spices with ground coconut-shell ; and the numberless other practices by which unscrupulous greed thrives at the expense of public health.
"This evil is not confined to the United States. The reports of European chemists and official investigators show that similar methods are obtained abroad.
Lloyds Now" of London, January 19th 1908 has this to say on the subject of Adulteration of Food.

"The annual report of the operations ander the sale of Food and Drugs Act has just been published, and it shows that adulteration is still regarded as a fine art. Out of 60,000 samples of milk, butter, and choice which were examined in 1906 it was found that over 11 percent of milk, 7 percent of butter, and a comparatively small percentage of chewe were adulterated in various ways. The difficulty arises principally in the areas of small local authorities with limited resources. It is on record that in one district of about 4,000 inhabitants margarine isi habitually substituted for water because, owing to the incompetence of the only officer who can be employed as a mpling official, the unitary authority is able to take proceedings. The obvious deduction is that if the laws are to be put in force greater powers must be given to the local authorities, and more stringent demand must be made for the application of those powers without respect of persons
As an example of political morals: the French-law may be cited, which prohibits the coloring of vegetables by copper for domestic , but permits it for exportation !

"In Germany the adulteration of wine and beer is prohibited for home consumption but permitted for portation. It is an open secret that wine from enna and beer from Munich are "doctored' for shipping to the United States.
"This price of "fixing," so called, for the American constimer, is practiced by the bottlers of a mineral water, "made in Germany where the water is salted" for exportation.
"Our European neighbours object to being poisoned themselves, but do not mind turning an honest (1) ponny in poisoning us!

"Here is where Major Carson's Bureau of manufactures is invaluable to the American consumer. From his special agents sent abroad from time to time to various countries, the bureau obtains full information respecting the fabrication of impure and unwholesome foods and thus enables our home authorities to prevent their introduction into American markets. This special service cannot be done by consuls or diplomats.

"Under international law they are regarded as the creatures of the nation which sends them and the nation which receives them and the moment they make themselves non grata, they have to be recalled or transfered.

"Suppose, for instance, a consul at Marseilles ascertained the & merchant there was exporting sardines which contained ptomaines, and reported the fact at Washington. When the news got back to Marseilles, as it would in sixty days, what would be that therchant's feelings toward the consul, and how long would it be before he lodged a protest in Paris against this Yankee interference with a Frenchman's rights t'
"How soon would the Marseilles press denounce the presumption and small mindedness And arrogance of the American Consult
"How long before the French Government informed our own at Washington that the Console was a persona non grata 1 Fortunately for us it is now different with the Bureau of manufacturer

"The special ent now gathers all the facts at Marseilles out of trouble or delay. These Agents of the Waren are experts and independent of all political, legal, and sociare lations and ties, and, being the servants of a Government Bureau at Washington, their personality abroad never enters into the matter.

"The success of this important work, of course, depends on the personality of the agents. They dedicated trained and traveled men. In many instances they are college graduates, linguists, men with a knowledge of chemistry, microscopy, foreign languages and commercial relations.
"To select such men demands talent, but it has been done by Chief Carson with satisfactory results demonstrated in the reforms effected and vast increase of American commerce."

div.head: EGYPTIAN GIRLS' EDUCATION. THE SANIEH SCHOOL.
div.p: Of all the modern educational institutions in Cairo, none is more interesting from a woman's point of view than the Sanieh Girls' School and Training College at Bab-el-Nasrieh, where the rising generation of Egypt's daughters are being educated on lines adopted from the best of English and Arabic methods.

Though the present airy building surrounded by its play groups etc. has been only in existence some four years, the sehool owes its foundation to the generosity of the late Princess Autsinghi Hanem, whose death only occurred some few months ago, and whose portrait dated 1867 when the institution was inaugurated now change in entrance hall opposite that of the late Kl live Ismail Pasha. The original school was used amid native sur. roundings in one of the old streets in the same neighbourhood; and it was not until years ago that the Government placed it under the control of an English resident boed. mistress. The present head, Miss K. J. Johnstone has occupied this position now for over six years, during which period many medical reforms have been affected in the régime; and to-day the Sanieh Sobool is in a mout flourishing condition, oddparents most favourably with any of our big blue girl's school at home, and is a very excellent sample of the good that is being done for young Egypt by the present Government. At the present moment some 265ghter of well-to-do Beds, many Membuat beret receiving & sound and practical education According to the most approved methods, while in the training college some fifty sta. dents are being equipped to take their place as teachers to the rising generation.

The school and grounds cover a wide area which is jealously guarded from outside view by means of high walls and sorok The main buildings take the form of a hollow square on losing a well kept garden; wide Tomadaha and corridor leading to the various class rooms and dormitories all of which overlook she garden. Various detached building are plastered round the war and one side of the wain one; dining ball, kiteber, model laundry and work rooms, while on the other side to hoe the huge playground containing its private mosque, Wolters from the sun. drinking fountain to., where the children have many happy hours in creation. Beyond the playground stand the comfortable detached house where the staff of English trained and certificated teachers & tennis court being provided for their private use, the tidad mistress having her private suite And office in the main building.

The classrooms are all bright airy apartments furnished throughout with comfortable desks, black boards etc. just one knows them at home. Each class is composed of thirty pupils, there being three classes in the preparatory division, junior to those belonging to the regular course which covers a period of four years. There are many pupils of five years old in the baby classes, where the ins traction is mostly after the kindergarten type Reading and writing in both English and Arabic from text books carefully compiled for the purpose, needlework and other simple pursuits occupy the attention of the smaller children; who when they are drafted into the first year of the primary course start on a curriculum which includes all the usual subjects, simple sciences, domestic economy, M well as those prescribed by their religion and country.

After the four years' course is completed, the would-be students pass on to the training college, which is a comparatively new development. The students commence their further studies at about the age of fourteen, and after three years spent in theoretical work, they still have a father counsel of two years which they spend in practical teaching in the school under supervision before they aan bopo to gain their diplomas. The classrooms belonging to the training college are quite distinct from the remainder of the school, and the abundents have the use of a reading room and library, and also a studio where black-board drawing as well as perspective and free hand drawing are taught.

Though the bulk of the scholars are day borders, there are nearly eighty who live on the premises : their dormitories occupying the tapper story of the building. Everything is done to make them happy and comfortable : there is a small hospital, rarely ever used luckily, and the numerous bath rooms are all furnished with hot and cold water.

Many happy hour are spent by the children in the little museum lately fitted for them, and e where they are encouraged to bring specimens and their collections of antiguas; and the workroom is in great favour, the pupils showing a wonderful aptitude in the craft of the redlo, both plain stitchery and elaborate embroidery being equally well executed. Drill and physical training also figures largely on the programme; and during the winter evenings frequent lantern entertainments are given in the dining hall. This last one is mentioned. hall is a fine detached building, its space occupied by of many small tables each one seating seven small e children and one older girl who presides over them. The diet is plentiful and wholesome as may be seen from the specimen menu taken at random.
Breakfast. Bread, eggs, milk and tea.
Dinner. Minced beef, beans, rice, and oranges.
Tea. Oakes, biscuits, milk and tes.
Dinner. Roast beef, potatoes, marrow, macaroni and rice puddings

In an article of this length it is scarcely possible to dilate upon the things that strike one most on visiting this school. The brightness and eberm of it all, the happy faces of pupils the openness of their teachers, and the capable management of the head are all evident at night and it is only when one games to consider the details which go to make the school what it is, that superficial impressions are lost in the appreciation of the difficulties that have been so successfully overcome.

div.head: THE HISTORY OF EGYPT.
div.p: The Rev. R. MacInnes M.A. gave the first of a course of lectures on the History of Egypt st Connaught House on Thursday, after noon, a fair audience taking advantage of the coasion to add to their store of knowledge on the interesting subject. 4x the course is only to include four lectures and the subject is a very long one, it is not possible to dwell long on any one period; but the Rev. MacInnes's introductory lecture was immensely interesting and gave a good birds eye view of the earliest history of this wonderful country. Unfortunately the illustrations to the lecture which were to have been given by lantern slides were to be omitted, but they will doubtless be seen at the next meeting on February 27.

Starting with the geological formation of Egypt, in the very far off days of some fifty thousand years ago, the lecturer told how this land, the latest of the earth's formation, was not one of the first to be inhabited. He described the formation of the deep ravine between the bigh lande of t bar East and West and the scouring of the mountain side as the torrential river pushed through the deep cleft, carrying the debris with it, which in later years formed the fertile valley and plains of the delta For in the earliest days the sea undoubtedly stretched inland as far as Cairo, and the climate was laden with moisture, so that the heights on either side of the river, which we know. As arid desert, were covered with rieb vegetation Animal life Shere may have been in the valley : but the paleolithic human inhabitants must have lived in the heights ; and the only remains which tell of their existence are the flint implements found round about the Luxor hills, which from their discolouration must have been chipped and carved and used not less than fifty thousand years ago. Long centuries rolled between those days and the period belonging to what is known as the prognostic inhabitants of Egypt. Remains of these are of frequent occurrence; and from them many interesting facts have been deduced. They evidently had some form of religion, and though they had no literature, their sense of art was wonderful; and as time went on their weapons marked the transition between the stone and metal ages. Their small holdings or village encampments became tused into larger townships under one chief till eventually the valley of the Nile was divided only into two kingdoms which eventually were united under Menes, the first king of the first dynasty. For the subsequent history of early Egypt we are indebted to the compilations of Menethil, which though lacking in detail and accuracy have been enriched And elaborated by the subsequent discoveries of Egyptologists. The lecturer traced the evolution of these dynasties, tracing their rise and fall, their various periods of renaissance and decadence : eliminating those which were of no practical bearing on the evolution of the country, from the time of Menes the first King of the first period to those wonderful empire makers and empire builders of the eighteenth and nineteenth dynasties who set their boundaries where they would, and filled the country with those marvellous mementos of their wealth and power.

div.head: ASSOUAN.
div.p: Upper Egypt In this far desert land of sweet repose Where fertile spots infringe the lovely Nile, And gentle zephyrs, sighing where it down, Seem all that's best in nature to beguile The tired human, wearied by the strife Where competition held his mind enthralled Sleeps, but to wake unto a fairer life, A dreamland where the past is unrealed. 0. MIND LETON January 12, Ims.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEK REPORT
LIVERPOOL, 16 January
There has been very little doing in Egyptian cotton this week, prices however remain firm and are to per lb dearer.
In Futures a moderate business has been done, and the following are the latest values:Jan. 9.36 Apr. 9.84 July 9.84 9. 9.32 Peb. 9,35 May 9.34 Aug. 9.84 Nov. 9.81 Mar. 9.35 June 9.34 Sept. 9.333

AMERICAN FUTURES. The Market this week has been more active, and although there have been several fluctuations the tendency throughout has been upwards, and today's closing values are 27 points higher for the current month and January/February delivery: 981 26 points higher for the intermediary solutions, and 171 @ 185 points higher for X Crops, than those of last Thursday. The ad 200 has been chiefly due to smaller crop moments, and to a strong Bull manipulation emanating from New York, and rumoured to have influential people at the head of it. At the same time the smaller receipts have again brought into prominence the smaller crop estimates, notably Messrs. Neill Bros. who reiterate their previous estimate of 11,600,000, and at the same time estimate the consumption of American cotton at 12,600,000. These figures would be very strong if one would be sure that they would prove correct. The Bank rate has been reduced to 5 %, which is an undoubted relief, and there are good hopes that the difficulties atween the spinners and the operatives will be arranged.

The latest quotations are delivered January 6.99) April/May 6.004 Aug. 6.841 Jan./Feb. 8.997 Mayflyne 4,00 Sept. / .721 | Feb/Mar 6.90 and July 6.984 Odt./Nov, 562 | Mar.(Apl. 6,00) July Aug. 6,96 Nov./Der 9.01 |

div.p: Messieurs les Actionnaires sont convoqués à l'Assemblée Générale Ordinaire qui aura lieu le Vendredi 31 Janvier 1908 * 3 heures de l'après-midi au Siège social au Caire, ORDRE DU JOUR ! 1. Lecture du Rapport du Conseil d'Admi nistration sur les affaires sociales 2. Lecture du Rapport des Censeurs ; 8. Approbation des comptes et fixation da dividende pour l'exercice 1907; 4. Nomination d'Administrateurs ; 5o. Nomination de deux Censeurs pour l'e mercice 1908. Tout porteur de 50 antions a le droit d'assister à l'Assemblée Générale et conformément à l'article 28 des statuts, les actions devront être déposées : En Egypte : au plus tard le 30 Janvier 1908. En Europe : au plus tard le 20 Janvier 1908. Les dépots seront reçus : au Caire : au Siège social; Alexandrie: au Crédit Lyonnais ; A la Banque de Paris et des Pays Bas, su Orédit Lyonnais, à la Société Générale pour fa. en Europe voriser le développement du Commerce et de l'Industrie en France, au Comptoir National d'Escompte, à la Société Générale de Crédit Ind. & Commercial. 31589-5-5

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Vendredi, 24 Janvier

La tenue d'aujourd'hui est tout l'opposé de celle d'hier. La baisse des taux d'escompte tant à Londres qu'à Paris ayant contribué à ranimer les espéranoes, plusieurs valeurs ont bénéficié d'une reprise appréciable. De plus, des échanges effectifs ont eu lieu sur toute la cote.
En raison de la hausse de Londres, la National Bank aencore gagné environ une demi-livre 22, mais les affaires ont été à peu près Dulles, faute de vendeurs sur place.
L'Agricole est beaucoup plus ferme à 7 25/32, contre 7 11/16 hier.On a fait beaucoup de bruit autour de ce titre surtout au moment de la cotation, dans le bat évident de le faire coter plus haut.

Après avoir progressé de 1 17/32 & 1 5/8, la Building Lands a fini vendeurs à 1 1/2. Ce Albchissement est attribué aux réalisations hypothène asser naturelle quand on so rappelle que le cours était récemment encore de 1 1/8.

L'Obligation Crédit Foncier a eu un mouvement assez anivi mais l'offre prédominante a fait fléchir le prix de 295 & 294 pour l'ancienne. Le cours de la nouvelle demeure sans change ment. Là encore le recul peut s'expliquer par les réalisations.
Il y a eu un réveil de la demande en Sidi Salem à 2 3/16. Des achats en Delta Land ont également fait monter le cours de 11/8 à 1 5/32.

LA Delta Light, recherchée, progresse de 9 5/8 à 9 21/32, ainsi que l'Alexandria Water de 10 3/8 à 10 1/2, la Béhéra de 20 & 20 1/8, le Comptoir de 2 5/16 à 2 3/8 et le Crédit Franco Egyptien de 4 1/8 4 4 5/32.

La hausse n'est cependant pas générale, puisque la Privilégiée Bière d'Alexandrie rétrograde de 100 a 95, la Land Bank de 7 1/2 à 7 7/16, l'Urbaine de 3 1/8 i 3, le Banco di Roma de 108 1/2 à 108 et la Port Said Salt de 10/9 & 10/6.
De 14/6 ls Salt & Soda avance A 15/

Il y a eu beaucoup d'affaires en Cassa di Sconto dont on annonce la prochaine Assem blée pour entendre le Rapport des liquidateurs. Sur le bruit, que nous reproduisons sous toute réserve, que sauf complications ultérieures, chaque motion recevrait 100 francs à la répar tition, le titre passé de 52 1/2 à 58 franes, avec tendance à la hausse.

Bref, l'ensemble de marché est bon et la tendance favorable. Le Caire, qui depuis assez longtemps nous inondait d'ordres de vente semble vouloir réabsorber one partie de ses sorties. S'il se maintient dans de telles dispositions, notre marché local ne pourra qo'y gagner Aveu d'aussi bonnes nouvelles du dehors et de la capitala on ne peut qu'être confiant dans l'avenir immédiat. La seule ombre au tableau ce sont les tentatives deja inaugurées par l'incorrigible spéculation pour créer des mouvements fnetices sur certaines valeurs. Il est le danger pour le moment, nous ne cesserons de le dénoncer.

Les banques ont joué, un grand role dans la crise égyptienne en accordant d'abord des crédits bien supérieurs ceux que méritaient les clients, puis en resserrant tout à coup ces crédits de façon à entrainer des faillites

Un des exemples les plus suggestifs de cette conduite financière est celui offert par la faillite Neggar Affit. Voici à ce sujet les chiffres que non extrayona da rapport du syndio de pond au grefle Commercial do tribunal mixte do Caire
Capital de la maison Neggar Affif au 31.12.06 P.T. 4.048 765,84
Montant des créances des Banques inscrites au pasif de la faillite, ad 7.12.07 62.022.549 Pog
Créances irrecouvrables. 7.000.000

Le rapprochement entre ces chiffres démontre qu'avec un capital relativement modeste, la maison Naggar Affif pouvait faire des affaires très considérables. Ce résultat était atteint : 1") par le crédit ouvert par les Banques à la dite maison sans garantie ; 2) par le système des tirages à trois mois renouvelés sans cesse ; 3) par le placement en gage près des Banques des titres appartenant aux clients.

En examinant l'analyse de la situation de la faillite faite par le syndio on trouve que, aux environs du mois de mai, toutes les banques ont commencé à resserrer le crédit et à réclamer des couvertures & MM. Naggar Afit. Au mois de Juin, ce resserrement de crédit a déjà porté ses effets: les faillis ne pouvant pas faire face aux exigences des banques, se trouvent mena cés de recours on justice. La faillite prononcée au mois de décembre fixe la suspension des payements au commencement d'aont. La succession de ces dates est la pren ve éloquente, ceci soit dit sans aucune intention de justifier les faillis, que la ruine de la maison NaggarAffif a été le resserrement du crédit des Banques locales et étrangèreo.

Si d'un ooté on ne peut blamer les banques d'avoir ainsi quoique tardivement asaini leur compte d'avances, on ne peut que s'étonner de leur complaisance passée et se demander comment des établissements chargés de régler le crédit ont pu sortir ainsi de leur rôle en favori sant la spéculation qu'elles ont ensuite abandonnée au moment oritique.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: TRIBUNAL MIXTE DU CAIRE
PROCÉS DES VILLAGEOIS D'ARMANT CONTRE La Daira SANIER Co. LTD. ET CONSORTS

La 2e Chambre Civile da Tribunal Mixte du Caire présidée par Mr. Vasquez & prononcé hier matin son jugement dans cette importante affaire dont les Avocats des parties étaient : Me Loutfi Ayrout Bey pour les villageois, Me Cadéminos pour les acheteurs et Me Pe traochi pour la Daira. Tout le monde applau. dira à la sagesse de ce jugement qui tranche une des questions qui ont passionné l'opinion publique.
Voici les principaux motifs sur lequels s'est basé le tribunal dans son jugement :

"Attendu que lorsque le Prince Moastapha Fazil eut venda ses propriétés en 1869 Ao Khé dive Ismail, il prit soin d'exclure de la vente 212 fed. et fractions ad teftiche d'Armanta Kebalet El Mallaha parmi lesquels se trouvaient 29 fed. et fractions occupés par l'Exbet de Wa. bourat Armant.

"Qu'en vertu de cette vente ni le Khedive Ismail ni la Daira Sanieh qui a puses lieu et placen'étaient propriétaires de cette quantité de terrain ; qu'ainsi la Société Egyptienne de la Daira Saniet qui a pris les lieu et place de l'Administration du même nom n'avait pas le droit de céder la propriété de cette Ezbeh ; que cette Société paraissait n'être pas bien sure elle-même de son droit de propriété puisqu'elle a stipulé la clause de non garantie dans l'acte de vente et a imposé aux acquéreurs l'obligation de revendre les habitations aux occupants ;" '

Le tribunal, examinant les conséquences juridiques de l'exclusion de cette parcelle de la vente faite par Moustapha Fazil à Ismail, déclaro que l'intention da prince était à n'en pas douter de consacrer les habitations, la mosquée, les routes, le cimetière et le marché de ce village a l'utilité publique.
Il a ensuite examiné le point de savoir si le Khedive Ismail ou la Daira Sanieh ont acquis la propriété de ces biens par la prescription de 15 ans ;

Il a dit à ce sujet qu'en admettant l'hypothese que le Khedive Ismail ait en la possession soit de longue durée, soit arbitrairement, il est constant que l'acquisition par cette possession ne pouvait être transférée à la Daira Sanieh tant que ces biens n'étaient pas compris dans l'inscription hypothécaire prise à la requête des créanciers de la Daira, qui forme le seul titre de propriété de celle-ci ;
Par ces Motifs,
Le tribonal déboute la Daira et ses acquéreurs de leur demande reconventionnelle tendant au déguerpissement des villageois de Fabet Wabourat Armant.

ORDRE DU JOUR :
1. Rapport du Conseil d'Administration sur le Bilan au 31 Décembre 1907 et Communication du Compte-rendu du Comité de liquidation
2.+ Rapport des Censeurs.
3. Réelection ou remplacement.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe.
Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.&O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

It is hardly necessary to point out to Tourists the extraordinary interest of a visit to Athens from an artistic, historical and archaelogical point of view, and if possible tourists should average to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara, for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture du Charbon de terre nécessaire à ses services durant l'année 1908. Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 30(Trente.) Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Techuique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés. Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 4 Février 1908. Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m. L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention "Soumission pour fourniture Charbon de terre." Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 4 février à midi. Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée. Alexandrie, le 18 Janvier 1908. L'Administraten 31794-3-2 (Signé) W.P. CHATAWAT.
